questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the role of telomerase in cellular ageing?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase accelerates ageing by reducing the length of telomeres with each cell division

options.label: B
options.text: Telomerase maintains the constant telomere length in somatic cells throughout their lifespan.

options.label: C
options.text: Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cell's lifespan.

options.label: D
options.text: Telomerase is a Ribozyme delaying cell aging.

questions.correct_answer: C. Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cell's lifespan.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the concept of the Hayflick Limit?

options.label: A
options.text: The ageing of cells is not determined by telomere length.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the age at which cells cease all metabolic activities and undergo apoptosis.

options.label: C
options.text: A cell typically undergoes 20-40 cell divisions before reaching senescence.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the average number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.

questions.correct_answer: D. It represents the average number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.

questions.text: How do “Sirtuins” contribute to cellular ageing?

options.label: A
options.text: By accelerating telomere shortening.

options.label: B
options.text: By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.

options.label: C
options.text: By functioning as histone acetyltransferases, promoting chromatin condensation.

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing insulin sensitivity

questions.correct_answer: B. By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.

questions.text: Which statement accurately distinguishes between hypertrophy and hyperplasia?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertrophy involves an increase in cell number, while hyperplasia involves an increase in cell size.

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertrophy increases tissue mass, while hyperplasia maintains tissue mass.

options.label: C
options.text: Hypertrophy is irreversible, while hyperplasia is reversible.

options.label: D
options.text: Hypertrophy results from increased cellular protein production, while hyperplasia involves growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Hypertrophy results from increased cellular protein production, while hyperplasia involves growth factor-driven proliferation of mature cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding for the past six months. She reports experiencing prolonged periods lasting more than ten days with excessive bleeding, abdominal discomfort, and pelvic pain during her menstrual cycle. On further evaluation, transvaginal ultrasound reveals thickening of the endometrial lining. Endometrial biopsy confirms the presence of abnormal glandular proliferation without cytologic atypia. Which of the following best describes the cellular adaptation observed in this clinical scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Physiological hypertrophy

options.label: B
options.text: Pathological hypertrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Physiological hyperplasia

options.label: D
options.text: Pathological hyperplasia

questions.explanation:
Definition

Examples

Physiological hypertrophy
(Option A)

Increase in the size of cells, resulting in organ enlargement due to increased functional demand or hormonal stimulation.
  • Uterine hypertrophy during pregnancy due to estrogenic hormone signalling.
  • Bulging of muscles in bodybuilders due to increased demand.

Pathological hypertrophy
(Option B)

Cell enlargement occurs in response to increased workload or stress. It typically occurs in tissues with limited capacity for cell division, such as cardiac or skeletal muscle.
  • Heart enlargement from hypertension or valvular disease.

Physiological hyperplasia
(Option C)

An increase in the number of cells in response to hormonal or growth factor stimulation in situations where there is a need to increase functional capacity or compensate for damage.
  • Breast glandular epithelium proliferation during puberty or pregnancy.
  • Liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy.
  • Bone marrow hyperplasia in response to blood cell deficiency.

Pathological hyperplasia
(Option D)

Occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue due to excessive or inappropriate hormonal or growth factor stimulation
  • Endometrial hyperplasia due to disturbance in estrogen-progesterone balance.
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia due to androgenic hormonal stimulation.

Note:

  • Pregnant uterus shows both hypertrophy (most common) and hyperplasia.
  • The single best answer is Hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of hypertrophy is inaccurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of G-protein-coupled receptor-initiated pathways

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulation of growth factor production such as TGF-β and IGF1

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of transcription factors like GATA4, MEF2, NFAT

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of downstream pathways including the PI3K/AKT pathway

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibition of transcription factors like GATA4, MEF2, NFAT

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Reduction in thymus gland size during ageing

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduction in thymus gland size during ageing

questions.text: Which type of metaplasia characterizes the histological changes observed in Barrett's oesophagus?

options.label: A
options.text: Transformation of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium

options.label: B
options.text: Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells

options.label: C
options.text: Conversion of glandular epithelium to squamous epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Substitution of mesenchymal cells with epithelial cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding metaplasia is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Metaplasia refers to the abnormal growth of cells, often leading to cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type.

options.label: C
options.text: Metaplasia is always a pathological process and never occurs in response to normal physiological stimuli.

options.label: D
options.text: Metaplasia is characterized by the replacement of differentiated cells with undifferentiated stem cells.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another adult cell type.
